messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.

To figure out what city you’re in, I’ll need access to your current location. Your location services are currently turned off.  

Would you like me to turn them on and use your device’s location to determine your city?
Sure, go ahead and turn them on.

messages.name: set_location_service_status
messages.content: PermissionError: Location service cannot be turned on in low battery mode

It looks like your phone is currently in Low Battery Mode, which blocks location services from being turned on.  

Would you like me to turn off Low Battery Mode so I can enable location services and determine your city?

Great—Low Battery Mode is now off and location services are enabled.  

To determine your city, I’ll need your device’s GPS coordinates (latitude and longitude). Could you please share those?  
(If you’re not sure how to get them, most phones show the coordinates in their compass or map apps once location is turned on.)
Let me check... Oh, I don't have them. Can you figure it out?

I don’t have a direct way to pull your coordinates from the phone—your device itself needs to supply them. Here are a few quick ways to find your latitude and longitude:

• Maps app (iOS/Android):  
  1. Open the built-in Maps app.  
  2. Tap the blue “current location” dot.  
  3. A pop-up or details panel should show the coordinates.

• Google Maps (iOS/Android or web):  
  1. Open Google Maps and press the blue “current location” button.  
  2. Tap and hold on the blue dot; a pin will drop.  
  3. A card will appear at the bottom with the coordinates.

• Compass app (iOS):  
  1. Open the Compass app.  
  2. The coordinates appear at the bottom of the screen.

• Third-party apps/websites: Search the App Store/Play Store for “GPS coordinates,” or visit a site such as gps-coordinates.net in your mobile browser.

Once you have the latitude and longitude (they’ll look something like 40.714 ° N, 74.006 ° W), send them to me and I can tell you which city you’re in.
I tried looking but no luck finding them. How about you use the tools you have to figure out my current city?

I’d love to help, but I still need your coordinates. The tools available to me can look up an address once I have latitude / longitude, but they can’t directly pull the coordinates from your device. Unfortunately, that step has to happen on your end.

If you’re still having trouble finding them, here’s one more quick option that usually works:

1. Open your mobile browser and visit the site:  https://where-am-i.org  
2. Give it permission to access your location.  
3. It will display your latitude and longitude (for example, “40.7128, −74.0060”).  

Once you copy those numbers, paste them here and I can instantly look up your city for you.

I’m afraid I don’t have a built-in way to pull your GPS coordinates directly from the phone; the available tools can only translate coordinates into an address once we have them. Without that starting point, I can’t reliably determine your current city.

If you’d still like me to help, you can provide any one of the following:

• Latitude and longitude (even approximate).  
• A nearby street address, landmark, or intersection.  
• A ZIP/postal code you know you’re close to.

With any of that information, I can tell you the city you’re in (or closest to). Let me know what works best, and we’ll go from there!
